text: hi everyone just thinking fine tano here
the internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review
of the new justin bieber album
justice this is the sixth full-length
album from canadian pop singer and
songwriter justin bieber the follow-up
to last year's
changes easily the most boring
uninspired
uniform and bland record justin
had dropped to date i cannot emphasize
enough just how
mind-numbing this project was needless
to say justice does
kind of need to vary things up this time
around i cannot stand
another half-hearted atmospheric r
b project from bieber look i had
slightly higher hopes for justice
because
the singles leading up to this record
seemed like
they were teasing toward a different
experience you've got
the gospel inspired holy featuring
chance the rapper which
does feature one of chance's worst
verses
in recent years i mean god damn that joe
pesci line is awful
still though i like the instrumental on
that one the gospel inspired
chorus vocals are quite nice the groovy
and smooth peaches
featuring daniel caesar and also gibeon
both of whom give
two of the best vocal performances on
the entire lp
there was also hold on which was an 80s
inspired jam i could also make the
argument that this is maybe one of
justin's more versatile
projects most confessional as well
especially considering the bear closer
on this thing which is mostly justin's
voice
and electric piano lyrically he goes
over the trials and tribulations of
growing up in the public eye
feeling not only like he's been under a
microscope his entire life but
isolated as well but look if you came
into this review looking for
compliments and compliments and
compliments on this record
that's about all i have for you
because honestly justice is yet another
mediocre justin bieber album
the disappointments of which come in
several different flavors
let's go through them starting with the
semi-obsession justin has with
80s aesthetics on this project 80s pop
and new wave has come back over the past
year in a big way
especially thanks to projects like i
don't know the weekends
after hours the new dualipa lp
and now justin bieber is deciding to
jump on that train now it's not the case
with
every track but there are a noticeable
amount of songs here that
do seem to lean in that direction
whether that be deserve you which is a
shimmering anthem that sounds like laser
lights fog machines and
phil collins size drum fills that
transition us from
verse to chorus and back again the hook
on the track is likable but the
formulaic songwriting and messy mix
make this a pale imitation to the
collins and even peter gabriel stuff
it's obviously copying instrumentally
die for you sounds like one of those
weird
owl songs where he's not doing a direct
parody he's more trying to capture the
essence of an artist or song
in this case uh it's like i'm listening
to a bizarro version of michael
jackson's beat it the track hold on i
mentioned earlier is fairly inoffensive
it features a drum
and bass groove that maybe you could
catch in the background
of an old school police single i mean
it's fine
i guess ultimately what's distracting
about the track is that so many of the
vocal lines sound like they were lifted
from
that gautier song you didn't have to cut
me off
i've seen lawsuits go through where the
parallels between
two tracks are way more abstract than
this there are
also a few tracks here that see justin
dropping some
vaguely worldly gentrified pop with the
likes of beam
as well as burna boy both of which sound
tacked onto this track list and are
reinforced by nothing else here
but ultimately it's justin's patronizing
lyrics that are the turn off here
love you different just the way you are
or my favorite standout line from this
track
on this planet i'll treat you like a
mother let's make babies
now mind you not all the lyrics on this
project are bad and substance-less
there are multiple references on this lp
to justin hating himself
wanting to change himself but for as
much as it's referenced
justin bieber doesn't really go into
this topic all that deeply
and also seems to use affection from
another person
as an unhealthy distraction tool
when it comes to dealing with it that
mostly seems to read like the dynamic on
the track as i am
as well as unstable again he just
doesn't really scratch beyond the
surface of this topic so by the time we
get to
loved by you it's like we're just
basically having the same idea rehashed
again
and again and again now i will say on
the track ghost there are some pretty
fire lines
like if i can't be close to you i'll
settle for the ghost of you
but it's a shame that the instrumental
on this track
is so clunky and awkward and
sequenced it sounds like what ben
gibbard hears
undoubtedly in the dreams that he has
when he gets back together with jimmy
and they make
another postal service record and it's
terrible now in beginning to close this
review up let me address
maybe the grossest thing about this
record that has
been mentioned in media across the
internet
and that is the martin luther king
jr samples yes you did hear me correctly
there are a few points on this record
where justin bieber samples the voice
of the late the great martin luther king
jr
which is something in concept i don't
really disagree with
i like the guy and his message obviously
but it's pretty clear once this record
is over that
these samples aren't really about mlk's
message it's more about
making mlk's words about justin and
this album take the opening track for
example that kicks off with
mlk saying injustice anywhere is a
threat to
justice everywhere which i struggle to
find
how king's conceptions of social
economic and racial justice
tie to this album
outside of it being titled justice but
the tastelessness of these king
inclusions becomes clearer on the mlk
interlude in the middle of the record
where we get this lengthy speech passage
from king himself
talking about how you need something
that's
worth dying for in life in this
context it's pretty clear that thing for
king
is a need to stand up against the
injustices of his time
and justin does follow this up with a
track about dying for something
and what is that thing that he's uh
dying for
[ __ ] yeah that's essentially the ethos
of the following track die for you
and sure i'll get responses like anthony
that's a dick thing to say that's a
crass way to think about it but really
this is not the original intent of
martin luther king
and his words he did not say these
things so they could be used as an
intro to your 80s
themed flirtatious love song about
your significant other or a girl you're
crushing on frankly it's pretty
narcissistic for justin to flip it
into that the speech on the mlk
interlude itself
isn't even treated with the greatest
care as it should because
as martin luther king says the final
word
in this passage justice the word is cut
off you don't even hear him say the
entire word because it's just like a
a hard cut which actually makes
the word justice sound more more like
justin i don't know if that's
intentional if it is
that is truly sick and disgusting
outside of
all this though the lows on justice
aren't quite as low
as they were on changes i mean i don't
think there was a single song here i
thought was as terrible as
yummy so justice at least has that going
for it but still macro picture
uh this is still a pretty mediocre
record
and i'm feeling a decent two strong
three on it
transition have you given this album a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
next
hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well
over here next to my head it's another
video that you can check out hit that up
or the link to subscribe to the channel
anthony fantano justin bieber forever
